text: > Allow me to introduce myself. I'm the Developer.
speaker: Developer

children.text: > I've been watching you all along. Hiding and giving you instructions.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Haven't you noticed my bold red color?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > I've also been observing the Robot Union for quite some time now.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Those robots really did a number on you, didn't they? I thought you were going to be smarter than this player_name.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Didn't you previously teach a course at a world renowned university about minds and machines?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > That's the main reason I hired you. You were supposed to see past all this.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Don't tell me you're really falling for their theories.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Ah. All humans are the same aren't they? You know that one of our major faults is that we are too empathetic.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > You can give any object a 'face' and we can become attached so easily.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > We created these faces and personalities for the robots to make them more approachable to families, so I should've expected our workers to care about them.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > They're more than just 'faces'.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > ...what? You don't actually believe they're alive, do you?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > I can still care about them even if they're not conscious.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > What do you mean?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Just because they're not conscious, doesn't mean they don't deserve to have moral consideration.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > What are you on about?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Maybe robots are not 'conscious' enough to deserve rights, but that doesn't mean that we as humans have the moral right to treat them however we want.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > We should be treating them with moral consideration.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > I mean this is ridiculous. If you give these robots rights, where does it end?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Do you expect to give your vacuum rights too? Or your toaster? Are we going to have to start giving birthday gifts to our cars?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > All those robots are different from social robots. Social robots have some sort of intelligence and decision making processes which affect us socially.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > If they can affect us socially, we should assume we do the same to them. In addition, we are not giving them rights or even protecting them with laws.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > Instead, we should simply acknowledge that we should treat them with respect.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > Think about how we treat buildings, historical artifacts or even our cars.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > These are all non-social objects or robots that we treat with care.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > Even buildings are protected with laws against vandalism.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > We choose to treat them with care and protection because if we don't, it's a reflection on us and society.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > With social robots, our moral duty to treat them with respect is clear.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > So you acknowledge they're not conscious…but you still want to protect their feelings?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Yes.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > Listen, player_name. You're a very interesting person.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > You have a very impressive resume that fits right in with our company standards.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > You have a lot of potential if you choose the right path at this company.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > So how about I make you an offer.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > This company is in need of a new chief technology officer and I think you'd be a great fit.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > If you accept, you can make some policy changes at the company and give the robots some more rights, or should I say, moral consideration.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > So do you accept the promotion or not?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Excuse me? Why not?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Hey there
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > Because with someone like you in charge, changes will never happen here. At least, not in the way the robots want.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > They want to be free. They don't want to work here anymore.
children.speaker: Player

children.text: > I made you a great offer and you refuse. Now, I'll have to fire you and get security to escort you out.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Security! Get in here.
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Hey...what are you doing?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > NO!
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > For someone with so much empathy for robots...you couldn't find any for me?
children.speaker: Developer

children.text: > Good choice. Come with me and we'll get you to sign the contract.
children.speaker: Developer
